items.title: Pope Leo arrives in Turkey on closely watched 1st overseas trip
items.summary_auto: Pope Leo arrived in Turkey on his first trip outside Italy as leader of the Catholic Church on Thursday. He was expected to make appeals for peace in the Middle East and urge unity among long-divided Christian churches.

items.title: Dozens of women plan class action lawsuit against Toronto club promoter, several nightlife companies
items.summary_auto: Dozens of women have come forward with allegations of negligence by some of the biggest companies in Toronto’s nightlife industry in connection to decades of alleged abuse by a well-known club promoter, according to a Canadian advocacy organization for survivors of abuse.

items.title: ‘It’s not rocket science’: Diabetic says getting coverage under N.S. programs a struggle
items.summary_auto: A Type 1 diabetic who recently moved to Nova Scotia said they paid hundreds of dollars out of pocket while trying to apply for provincial programs that help cover the costs of insulin and supplies.

items.title: A rare photosynthesizing sea slug has been found off N.S. Here's why scientists are excited
items.summary_auto: Researchers believe Elysia chlorotica holds promise for medical advances, but it's been too elusive to study.

items.title: She found the Amelia Earhart statue but instead of a reward, she's become a suspect
items.summary_auto: Instead of receiving a big cash reward, the woman who found the stolen Amelia Earhart statue says her life has become a nightmare.

items.title: Charity for first responders disbands amid fraud allegations against CEO, treasurer
items.summary_auto: A charity for Canadian first responders and their families is suing its former CEO and treasurer, alleging massive fraud and misappropriation of donor funds. CBC News has learned that the Hamilton-based Canadian Critical Incident Stress Foundation quietly ceased operations late last year and is suing former CEO Renee Jarvis and her daughter, former treasurer Kelsey Pitt.

items.title: Hundreds of animals killed by trains on B.C. railroads, documents reveal. So, what’s being done to stop it?
items.summary_auto: Documents obtained through freedom of information requests by The Narwhal and shared with CBC News show hundreds of animals have been killed in collisions with trains on B.C. tracks owned by Canada's two biggest railways. Scientists and advocates say if the information was more complete and accessible, it could be used to reduce the number of animals killed.

items.title: After a spate of fatal crashes, coroner's office calls for clearer definition of e-bikes in Ontario
items.summary_auto: An expert panel is calling on the Ontario government to tighten its definition of what counts as an e-bike, in an attempt to improve safety and reduce the number of fatal crashes.

items.title: If the grizzly that attacked a B.C. school group is found, what happens next?
items.summary_auto: Efforts to locate the bear that attacked a school group near Bella Coola, B.C., last Friday are still underway. The rare attack that injured four people is prompting questions about what should happen to the animal if it's found.

items.title: Italian actresses say country has become safe haven for men accused, found liable of sex assault
items.summary_auto: While Hollywood, Canada and other parts of Europe have confronted allegations against powerful men through the #MeToo movement, Italy has become a land where directors and actors facing multiple accusations, or who have been found guilty or civilly liable for sexual assault, continue to work freely.

items.title: Ontario could avoid recession this year, even as Trump's tariffs take hold: fiscal watchdog
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s fiscal watchdog says the province could avoid a recession this year, but the findings of his latest report show the trade war with the U.S. is taking a bite out of Ontario’s economy. The data is part of the latest update from the province’s Financial Accountability Office.

items.title: Montreal mayor, STM say efforts being made to curb rise in transit violence
items.summary_auto: Montreal transit officials and the city’s new mayor say they are taking steps to address growing concerns about safety on the city’s bus and Metro systems following a CBC analysis showing a rise in transit-related assaults in major Canadian cities.

items.title: Conservatives have a new campaign manager. How much has really changed?
items.summary_auto: After feeling the chance to form government slip through their fingers, many Conservatives are publicly gushing over their party’s choice to lead the next campaign. But the question still hanging in the air is just how much will actually change.

items.title: Is this actually the first image of dark matter?
items.summary_auto: What we see in our universe only accounts for roughly five per cent of what’s out there. The remaining 95 per cent is invisible. But now, a researcher at the University of Tokyo says he's seen at least part of that invisible universe.

items.title: Coroner's office calls for clearer definition of e-bikes in Ontario
items.summary_auto: An expert panel is calling on the Ontario government to tighten its definition of what counts as an e-bike, in an attempt to improve safety and reduce the number of fatal crashes.

items.title: #TheMoment a sea lion lunged at cold plungers
items.summary_auto: Andrew Wierzbicki and Ennio Titarenko tell The National about the moment a large sea lion lunged at them while they were cold plunging in Victoria, B.C.

items.title: B.C. man who bought drugs for compassion club surprised by Health Canada's lack of 'urgency' on crisis
items.summary_auto: A co-founder of Vancouver's Drug User Liberation Front said he was surprised by Health Canada's lack of "urgency" about the deadly toxic drug crisis, and the absence of a pharmaceutical-grade supplier meant the club had to turn to the dark web to get pure substances.

items.title: Family medicine clinic in Hudson, Que., to close citing Quebec's Bill 2
items.summary_auto: A family medicine clinic in Hudson, Que., west of Montreal, will close citing the implementation of Quebec's controversial Bill 2.

items.title: Gordon Lightfoot's performance guitar sells for more than $300,000 at estate auction
items.summary_auto: A large collection of personal items belonging to legendary Canadian musician Gordon Lightfoot, like awards, instruments and rare photographs, were auctioned off today by A.H. Wilkens in Toronto.

items.title: A look back at secularism laws in Quebec ahead of another bill limiting religion
Sask. government to renew $10-a-day child care deal on Friday: premier
items.summary_auto: Premier Scott Moe says Saskatchewan will sign a renewed deal with Ottawa to extend the federally subsidized $10-a-day childcare program.

items.title: Louis Plamondon honoured as MP with longest continuous service in Canadian history
items.summary_auto: Louis Plamondon is now the longest continuously serving member of Parliament in Canadian history, with his colleagues in the House of Commons honouring him for his record of service.

items.title: Two key North Coast B.C. leaders meet with Alberta premier ahead of federal pipeline MOU
items.summary_auto: The mayor of Kitimat, B.C. and elected chief of the Haisla First Nation say they reminded Alberta Premier Danielle Smith of the longstanding opposition to an oil pipeline in the region.

items.title: Federal Indigenous Art Collection has over 100 artworks 'not accounted for'
items.summary_auto: Officials with Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs Canada are looking to track down over 100 works of Indigenous art held in a federal collection that are unaccounted for.

items.title: The Miss Universe drama somehow got worse. Is this the pageant's breaking point?
items.summary_auto: The  chaos of this year's Miss Universe pageant didn't end after Mexico's Fátima Bosch Fernández was crowned the winner last week in a competition plagued by bullying, a hospitalization and allegations of vote rigging. Some contestants have now renounced their titles while other have spoken out about controversies surrounding the event.

items.title: Woman dies after waiting over 30 hours for care in Manitoba, family says
items.summary_auto: Manitoba health officials are investigating a critical incident after the family of an 82-year-old woman said she died following a more than 30-hour wait for hospital care in last week.

items.title: 'System is broken,' nurse says after her mother's death following more than 30-hour wait for care
items.summary_auto: Manitoba health officials are investigating a critical incident after the family of an 82-year-old woman said she died following a more than 30-hour wait for hospital care in last week.

items.title: FBI to investigate motive in D.C. shooting as Trump administration deploys more National Guard members
Mother 'disgusted' after Hamilton man found not criminally responsible in cousin's stabbing death
items.summary_auto: A Hamilton man who stabbed his cousin to death in 2023 has been found not criminally responsible, a Superior Court judge ruled Wednesday.

items.title: How will Stranger Things' final season end? Fans have many theories on that
items.summary_auto: Stranger Things fans will finally get some answers when Season 5 drops Wednesday — but that's not stopping them from speculating about who might die or how the show’s villains might be defeated. They say whether they’re right or wrong, it's fun to predict how the beloved series will come to a close.

items.title: Year after quadriplegic Quebec man chose assisted dying, advocates prepare class action
items.summary_auto: Advocates and the widow of a quadriplegic Quebec man are preparing to file a class-action lawsuit against the province after the 66-year-old requested medical assistance in dying following a hospital stay last year that left him with a severe bedsore.
